what: Streamlining longitudinal microbiome profiling in Bioconductor
title: LegATo Tutorial
text: Microbiome time-series data presents several distinct challenges, including complex covariate dependencies variety longitudinal study designs. Furthermore, several individual tools created aid longitudinal microbiome data analysis, -inclusive R-based toolkit remained elusive. address concerns, created LegATo (Longitudinal mEtaGenomic Analysis TOolkit). LegATo suite open-source software tools longitudinal microbiome analysis extendable several different study forms, promising optimal ease--use researchers. toolkit allow researchers determine microbial taxa affected time perturbations onset disease lifestyle choices, predict effects perturbations time, including changes composition stability commensal bacteria. Currently, LegATo entertains number data cleaning, aggregation, modeling testing procedures. develop learn new methods, add toolkit accordingly. soon add hierarchical clustering tools multivariate generalized estimating equations (JGEEs) adjust compositional nature microbiome data.

what: Compatibility with MultiAssayExperiment and SummarizedExperiment objects
title: LegATo Tutorial
text: convenience LegATo part credited integration MultiAssayExperiment SummarizedExperiment objects. reliable clean data structures developed part MultiAssayExperiment SummarizedExperiment packages. MultiAssayExperiment container concisely stores SummarizedExperiment object, aggregates data matrices along annotation information, metadata, reduced dimensionality data (PCA, t-SNE, etc.). learn proper usage context objects, may want take look MultiAssayExperiment package vignette SummarizedExperiment package vignette. install two packages, run following code:
code: if (!requireNamespace("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))     install.packages("BiocManager")  BiocManager::install("MultiAssayExperiment") BiocManager::install("SummarizedExperiment")

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: install development version LegATo Github, run following code: Now ’ll load LegATo package library: purposes vignette, ’ll also load ggeffects emmeans library:
code: BiocManager::install("wejlab/LegATo") library(LegATo) library(ggeffects) library(emmeans) ## Welcome to emmeans. ## Caution: You lose important information if you filter this package's results. ## See '? untidy'

what: Formatting input data for use with LegATo
title: LegATo Tutorial
text: LegATo functions expect data properly formatted MultiAssayExperiment container, naming conventions compatible animalcules. Obtaining properly formatted data can achieved easily via create_formatted_MAE() function LegATo package, detailed .

previous_headings: Formatting input data for use with LegATo
what: A note on compatibility with other packages
title: LegATo Tutorial
text: ’ve analyzed metagenomic 16S data via MetaScope package, can aggregate sample outputs user-input metadata using MetaScope::convert_animalcules() MetaScope::convert_animalcules_silva() functions prior loading data LegATo. functions create taxonomy table collate data LegATo- animalcules-compatible MultiAssayExperiment object. can also format data analyzed elsewhere (e.g., PathoScope 2.0 Kraken) animalcules package upload step R Shiny app, select “Download Animalcules File” obtain MAE object can used LegATo.

previous_headings: Formatting input data for use with LegATo
title: LegATo Tutorial
text: purposes example, ’ll look example inputs unrelated main HIV-E infant data: counts table composed raw microbial counts. one row taxon, one column sample. tax table composed taxonomy lineages. one row taxon, number columns taxonomic level (e.g., superkingdom, genus, species). lowest level taxonomy serves rownames table, also stored column. Taxonomic levels increase granularity left right. sample table contains entries sample, unique sample IDs rows. columns metadata samples, subjects units repeated measures taken, groupings, pairings, covariates. rownames(counts) == rownames(tax) colnames(counts) == colnames(sample) Now ’ll look formatting : Counts Table Preview Taxonomy Table Preview Sample Table Preview
code: counts <- system.file("extdata", "counts.csv", package = "LegATo") |>   read.csv(row.names = 1) |>   dplyr::rename_with(function(x) stringr::str_replace(x, "\\.", "-")) tax <- system.file("extdata", "tax.csv", package = "LegATo") |> read.csv(row.names = 1) sample <- system.file("extdata", "sample.csv", package = "LegATo") |> read.csv(row.names = 1) ndim <- 5 counts[seq_len(ndim), seq_len(ndim)] |>   knitr::kable(caption = "Counts Table Preview",                label = NA) tax[seq_len(ndim), ] |>   knitr::kable(caption = "Taxonomy Table Preview",                label = NA) sample[seq_len(ndim), ] |>   knitr::kable(caption = "Sample Table Preview",                label = NA)

previous_headings: Formatting input data for use with LegATo
title: LegATo Tutorial
text: data formatted correctly, can easily use create_formatted_MAE() like : data format TreeSummarizedExperiment, can call create_formatted_MAE(tree_SE) create MAE output compatible package.
code: output <- create_formatted_MAE(counts_dat = counts,                                tax_dat = tax,                                metadata_dat = sample)  class(output) ## [1] "MultiAssayExperiment" ## attr(,"package") ## [1] "MultiAssayExperiment" MultiAssayExperiment::assays(output) ## List of length 1 ## names(1): MicrobeGenetics SummarizedExperiment::assays(output[["MicrobeGenetics"]]) ## List of length 1 ## names(1): MGX

what: Adding information to your metadata later in your analysis
title: LegATo Tutorial
text: information needs added data object later point analysis, easiest manipulate raw data objects (potentially via parse_MAE_SE()) recreate MAE object create_formatted_MAE().

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: illustrate capabilities LegATo, turn published dataset following paper: Odom AR, Gill CJ, Pieciak R et al. Characterization longitudinal nasopharyngeal microbiome patterns maternally HIV-exposed Zambian infants [version 2; peer review: 2 approved reservations]. Gates Open Res 2024, 6:143 (https://doi.org/10.12688/gatesopenres.14041.2) raw dataset archived Zenodo: Zenodo: Underlying data ‘Characterization longitudinal nasopharyngeal microbiome patterns maternally HIV-exposed Zambian infants’. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.725531324 details dataset altered inclusion package provided .

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: example data consists 167 NP swabs healthy HIV-exposed, uninfected (HEU; n=10) infants HIV(+) mothers HIV-unexposed, uninfected (HUU; n=10) infants HIV(-) mothers. total 7 samples collected per infant, missingness data. swabs identified sample library collected Lusaka, Zambia 2015 2016. analysis objective parse association NP resident bacteria infant HIV exposure first 3.5 months (14 weeks) life, critical time microbiome maturation. data processed PathoScope 2.0, sample outputs aggregated animalcules R package. analysis, work infant data subset data accordingly. leaves us 129 samples analysis.
code: dat <- system.file("extdata", "MAE.RDS", package = "LegATo") |>   readRDS()  dat_subsetted <- MultiAssayExperiment::subsetByColData(dat,                                                        dat$MothChild == "Infant")

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: LegATo several functions manipulating MAE objects, delineated :

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: data aggregated via animalcules package, done example data, samples aggregated strain taxonomic level residual taxonomy IDs present. clean_MAE() function cleans data suffering issues.
code: dat_cleaned <- clean_MAE(dat_subsetted) ## Registered S3 method overwritten by 'rmutil': ##   method         from ##   print.response httr

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: Many metagenomic pipelines identify taxon abundances extremely small levels, can noisy deal analysis. filter_MAE function smoothly transforms reads belonging taxa overall genera threshold filter_prop (filter proportion) argument, set 0.005. filter_animalcules_MAE function utilizes filtering mechanism animalcules package:
code: dat_filt_1 <- filter_MAE(dat_cleaned, relabu_threshold = 0.05, occur_pct_cutoff = 10) ## The overall range of relative abundance counts between samples is (13218, 3016276) ## Number of OTUs that exhibit a relative abundance >0.05% in at least 10% of the total samples: 68/1136 dat_filt <- filter_animalcules_MAE(dat_cleaned, 0.05)

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: want take closer look data, can easily extract counts, taxonomy, sample metadata tables using parse_MAE_SE() function. Counts Table Sample Metadata Taxonomy Table
code: parsed <- parse_MAE_SE(dat_filt, which_assay = "MicrobeGenetics", type = "MAE")  parsed$counts[seq_len(5), seq_len(5)] |>    knitr::kable(caption = "Counts Table") parsed$sam[seq_len(5), ]  |>   knitr::kable(caption = "Sample Metadata") parsed$tax[seq_len(5), ] |>    knitr::kable(caption = "Taxonomy Table")

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: fairly convenient summarize average number reads report get_summary_table(). table groups user-provided discrete covariates. Summary Table get_top_taxa function outputs data.frame lists taxa order relative abundance. Table genera, ranked abundance
code: group_vars <- c("HIVStatus", "MothChild") get_summary_table(dat_filt, group_vars) |>   knitr::kable(caption = "Summary Table", label = NA) best_genus <- get_top_taxa(dat_filt, "genus") best_genus |> knitr::kable(caption = "Table of genera, ranked by abundance")

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: want conduct analyses, get_long_data() function prove convenient. get_stacked_data() function can used certain visualizations utilize relative abundance aggregation approach.
code: longdat <- get_long_data(dat_filt, "genus", log = TRUE, counts_to_CPM = TRUE)  stackeddat <- get_stacked_data(dat_filt, "genus", covariate_1 = "HIVStatus",                                covariate_time = "timepoint")

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: several plots can visualize changes relative abundance time, accounting given covariate. case, interested HIV exposure. ’ll select palette using paletteer.

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: Alluvial diagrams illustrate individual taxa stream fields change position different time points. height stream field represents relative abundance taxon. given time point, stream fields ranked highest lowest abundance (top bottom). can constructed plot_alluvial().  context, plot indicates high abundance Staphylococcus control HIV-E infants first two weeks life, genera quickly overtake Staphylococcus dominance shown changing rank streams time point. Overall, Streptococcus seems far greater presence HIV-E infants’ nasopharyngeal microbiota
code: plot_alluvial(dat = dat_filt,                taxon_level = "genus",                covariate_1 = "HIVStatus",               covariate_time = "timepoint",               palette_input = this_palette,               subtitle = "Alluvial plot")

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: can create spaghetti volatility plots elucidate changes time sample level given taxon. advantageous visualization methods often aggregates multiple samples lack granularity. plots can created plot_spaghetti().  plot changes Staphylococcus log counts per million (CPM) across time points. spaghetti plot format clues us outlier infants control group seem extremely high counts first weeks life.
code: plot_spaghetti(dat = dat_filt,                covariate_time = "timepoint",                covariate_1 = "HIVStatus",                unit_var = "Subject",                taxon_level = "genus",                which_taxon = "Staphylococcus",                palette_input = this_palette,                title = "Spaghetti Plot",                subtitle = NULL) +   ggplot2::xlab("Infant Age (timepoint)") +   ggplot2::ylab("Relative Abundance (log CPM)")

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: Stacked bar plots used visualize relative abundance microbes given taxonomic level sample, represented single bar, labeled time point, plotted within HIV exposure status group separate mothers infant comparisons. Use plot_stacked_bar.  see stacked bar plots many microbes seem maintain similar trends control HIV-E infants time, Streptococcus producing slightly higher abundances HIV-E group.
code: plot_stacked_bar(dat_filt, "genus",               "HIVStatus",              "timepoint",              palette_input = this_palette)

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: Stacked area charts similar stacked bar plots, provide continuity time points. created plot_stacked_area().  stacked area chart offers similar method visualizing data.
code: plot_stacked_area(dat_filt, "genus",                    "HIVStatus",                   "timepoint",                   palette_input = this_palette)

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: plot_heatmap, can plot heatmap specific microbe determine changes along one covariates.  heatmap, find clustering seem find clear relationship genera (rows) samples (columns). Three annotations plotted top bar: time point, HIV status, pairing.
code: this_taxon <- parsed$counts |>   animalcules::upsample_counts(parsed$tax, "genus") |>   animalcules::counts_to_logcpm() p <- plot_heatmap(inputData = this_taxon,                   annotationData = dplyr::select(parsed$sam, "timepoint", "HIVStatus", "pairing"),                   name = "Data",                   plot_title = "Example",                   plottingColNames = NULL,                   annotationColNames = NULL,                   colList = list(),                   scale = FALSE,                   showColumnNames = FALSE,                   showRowNames = FALSE,                   colorSets = c("Set1", "Set2", "Set3", "Pastel1", "Pastel2", "Accent", "Dark2",                                 "Paired"),                   choose_color = c("blue", "gray95", "red"),                   split_heatmap = "none",                   column_order = NULL ) ## Warning: The input is a data frame-like object, convert it to a matrix.

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: concrete analysis longitudinal microbiome data, LegATo provides NMIT, paired unpaired multivariate Hotelling’s T-squared test, generalized estimating equations (GEEs) linear mixed effects models (LMEMs/LMMs). brief overview method provided .

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: NMIT multivariate distance-based test intended evaluate association key phenotypic variables microbial interdependence. test determines longitudinal sample similarity function temporal microbial composition. authors thank Yilong Zhang providing code adaptation LegATo. Citations: Yilong Zhang, Sung Won Han, Laura M Cox, Huilin Li. multivariate distance-based analytic framework microbial interdependence association test longitudinal study. Genetic epidemiology, 41(8):769–778, 2017. doi:10.1002/gepi.22065.
code: dat_1 <- filter_MAE(dat_cleaned, 0.05, 10, "species") ## The overall range of relative abundance counts between samples is (13218, 3016276) ## Number of OTUs that exhibit a relative abundance >0.05% in at least 10% of the total samples: 46/1136 NMIT(dat_1, unit_var = "Subject", fixed_cov = "HIVStatus",      covariate_time = "timepoint",      method = "kendall", dist_type = "F",      heatmap = TRUE, classify = FALSE, fill_na = 0) ## Warning in stats::cor(x = df, y, method = method): the standard deviation is ## zero ## NULL

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: Hotelling’s T2 tests can used determine whether microbiome profiles exhibit notable differences trends across time groups. may use t-tests identify genera contributed differences. example, HEU HUU infants designated two sampling units relative abundances p abundant genera measured. paired tests, chose p = 6 variables ensure n < p singularity avoided T2 properly computed, n number measurements sampling unit. Normality met using microbe abundances log CPM units, calculated within function. Group comparisons can also tested unpaired data:
code: test_hotelling_t2(dat = dat_1,                   test_index = which(dat_filt$MothChild == "Infant" &                                        dat_filt$timepoint == 6),                   taxon_level = "genus",                   num_taxa = 6,                   paired = TRUE,                   grouping_var = "HIVStatus",                   pairing_var = "pairing") ## $df1 ## [1] 6 ##  ## $df2 ## [1] 2 ##  ## $crit_F ## [1] 19.32953 ##  ## $F_stat ## [1] 2.665069 ##  ## $pvalue ## [1] 0.2978084 test_hotelling_t2(dat = dat_1,                   test_index = which(dat_filt$timepoint == 0),                   taxon_level = "genus",                   num_taxa = 6,                   grouping_var = "HIVStatus",                   unit_var = "Subject",                   paired = FALSE) ## $df1 ## [1] 6 ##  ## $df2 ## [1] 13 ##  ## $crit_F ## [1] 2.915269 ##  ## $F_stat ## [1] 0.7611613 ##  ## $pvalue ## [1] 0.6127997

title: LegATo Tutorial
text: Generalized estimating equations (GEEs) described Liang Zeger (1986) extended Agresti (2002) widely used modeling longitudinal data, recently longitudinal microbiome data. genus present microbial aggregate samples, model normalized log CPM relative taxon counts, estimating effects time point HIV exposure status interaction, accounting underlying structure clusters formed individual subjects. GEE Outputs can also create plots covariates, saved folder specified user:
code: output <- run_gee_model(dat_1, unit_var = "Subject",                         fixed_cov = c("HIVStatus", "timepoint"),                         corstr = "ar1",                         plot_out = FALSE,                         plotsave_loc = ".",                         plot_terms = NULL)  head(output) |> knitr::kable(caption = "GEE Outputs") ## Warning: Some of the focal terms are of type `character`. title: LegATo: Longitudinal mEtaGenomic Analysis Toolkit
text: LegATo suite open-source software tools longitudinal microbiome analysis. extendable several different study forms optimal ease--use researchers. Microbiome time-series data presents distinct challenges including complex covariate dependencies variety longitudinal study designs. toolkit allow researchers determine microbial taxa affected time perturbations onset disease lifestyle choices, predict effects perturbations time, including changes composition stability commensal bacteria. LegATo integrates visualization, modeling testing procedures. currently development, soon supplemented hierarchical clustering tools multivariate generalized estimating equations (JGEEs) adjust compositional nature microbiome data.

title: Nonparametric Microbial Interdependence Test (NMIT) — NMIT
text: R-based implementation NMIT, multivariate distance-based test group comparisons microbial temporal interdependence. NMIT test provides comprehensive way evaluate association key phenotypic variables microbial interdependence. function recommended use filtering step using filter_MAE. Note, "ComplexHeatmap" package required use plotting features function. function requires "vegan" package.

title: Nonparametric Microbial Interdependence Test (NMIT) — NMIT
code: NMIT(   dat,   unit_var,   fixed_cov,   covariate_time,   method = "kendall",   dist_type = "F",   heatmap = TRUE,   classify = FALSE,   fill_na = 0,   ... )

title: Nonparametric Microbial Interdependence Test (NMIT) — NMIT
text: dat MultiAssayExperiment object specially formatted animalcules output. unit_var numeric vector subject. fixed_cov character vector names covariates interest found dat. covariate_time Character string giving name discrete time-based covariate metadata group abundances . method option correlation method ("pearson", "kendall", "spearman"). default method "kendall". dist_type character string specifying type matrix norm computed. default "F". * "M" "m" specifies maximum modulus   elements x; * "O", "o" "1" specifies one norm,   (maximum absolute column sum); * "" "" specifies infinity norm (maximum   absolute row sum); * "F" "f" specifies Frobenius norm (  Euclidean norm x treated vector) heatmap logical value indicating whether draw heatmap. default TRUE. classify logical value indicating whether draw classifier tree. default FALSE. fill_na number 0 1 fill NA values. default value 0. ... Additional arguments passed ComplexHeatmap::Heatmap().

title: Nonparametric Microbial Interdependence Test (NMIT) — NMIT
text: function returns analysis variance (ANOVA) table showing   sources variation, degrees freedom, sequential sums squares, mean   squares, F statistics, partial R-squared P values, based 999   permutations.

title: Nonparametric Microbial Interdependence Test (NMIT) — NMIT
text: Yilong Zhang, Huilin Li, Aubrey Odom

what: Create a formatted MultiAssayExperiment compatible with LegATo — create_formatted_MAE
title: Create a formatted MultiAssayExperiment compatible with LegATo — create_formatted_MAE
text: function takes either counts_dat, tax_dat, metadata_dat input TreeSummarizedExperiment input creates specifically-formatted MAE object compatible use LegATo animalcules. Checks performed inputs ensure can integrated properly.

title: Create a formatted MultiAssayExperiment compatible with LegATo — create_formatted_MAE
code: create_formatted_MAE(   counts_dat = NULL,   tax_dat = NULL,   metadata_dat = NULL,   tree_SE = NULL )

title: Create a formatted MultiAssayExperiment compatible with LegATo — create_formatted_MAE
text: counts_dat matrix, data.table, data.frame consisting microbial raw counts data. colnames sample names rownames order tax_dat entries. required tree_SE passed . tax_dat matrix, data.table, data.frame hierarchical taxonomic data. columns "family", "genus", "species" row uniquely delineating different taxon. rows order rows counts_dat. required tree_SE passed . metadata_dat metadata table rownames equivalent samples colnames counts_dat. required tree_SE passed . tree_SE TreeSummarizedExperiment object counts, taxonomy, metadata.

title: Create a formatted MultiAssayExperiment compatible with LegATo — create_formatted_MAE
text: MultiAssayExperiment object.

title: Create a formatted MultiAssayExperiment compatible with LegATo — create_formatted_MAE
code: nsample <- ntaxa <- 3 counts_dat <- data.frame(     "X123" = runif(ntaxa, 0, 500),     "X456" = runif(ntaxa, 0, 500),     "X789" = runif(ntaxa, 0, 500) ) tax_dat <- data.frame(     "class" = c("rand1", "rand2", "rand3"),     "species" = c("rand4", "rand5", "rand6") ) |>     as.data.frame() # Set rownames as lowest unique taxonomic level rownames(tax_dat) <- tax_dat$species rownames(counts_dat) <- tax_dat$species metadata <- data.frame(     Sample = c("X123", "X456", "X789"),     Group = c("A", "B", "A"),     Var = rnorm(nsample) ) rownames(metadata) <- metadata$Sample out_MAE <- create_formatted_MAE(counts_dat, tax_dat, metadata)  # TreeSummarizedExperiment tse <- TreeSummarizedExperiment::TreeSummarizedExperiment(     assays = list(counts = counts_dat),     colData = metadata,                 rowData = tax_dat              ) out_MAE_2 <- create_formatted_MAE(tree_SE = tse) out_MAE_2 #> A MultiAssayExperiment object of 1 listed #>  experiment with a user-defined name and respective class. #>  Containing an ExperimentList class object of length 1: #>  [1] MicrobeGenetics: SummarizedExperiment with 3 rows and 3 columns #> Functionality: #>  experiments() - obtain the ExperimentList instance #>  colData() - the primary/phenotype DataFrame #>  sampleMap() - the sample coordination DataFrame #>  `$`, `[`, `[[` - extract colData columns, subset, or experiment #>  *Format() - convert into a long or wide DataFrame #>  assays() - convert ExperimentList to a SimpleList of matrices #>  exportClass() - save data to flat files

what: Generate a distinct palette for coloring different clusters. — distinctColors
title: Generate a distinct palette for coloring different clusters. — distinctColors
text: Create distinct palette coloring different heatmap clusters. function returns colors input ComplexHeatmap:Heatmap(). "grDevices" package required use function.

title: Generate a distinct palette for coloring different clusters. — distinctColors
code: distinctColors(   n,   hues = c("red", "cyan", "orange", "blue", "yellow", "purple", "green", "magenta"),   saturation.range = c(0.7, 1),   value.range = c(0.7, 1) )

title: Generate a distinct palette for coloring different clusters. — distinctColors
text: n integer describing number colors generate. Required. hues vector character strings indicating R colors available colors() function. used base colors clustering scheme. Different saturations values (.e. darkness) generated hue. Default c("red", "cyan", "orange", "blue", "yellow", "purple", "green", "magenta") saturation.range numeric vector length 2 values 0 1 giving range saturation. default c(0.25, 1). value.range numeric vector length 2 values 0 1 giving range values. default c(0.5, 1).

title: Generate a distinct palette for coloring different clusters. — distinctColors
text: vector distinct colors converted HEX HSV.

title: Generate a distinct palette for coloring different clusters. — distinctColors
code: distinctColors(10) #>  [1] "#FF4D4D" "#4DFFFF" "#FFC04D" "#4D4DFF" "#FFFF4D" "#BA4DFF" "#4DFF4D" #>  [8] "#FF4DFF" "#B30000" "#00B3B3"

what: Filter a MultiAssayExperiment object to keep a top percentage of taxa — filter_MAE
title: Filter a MultiAssayExperiment object to keep a top percentage of taxa — filter_MAE
text: function takes animalcules-formatted MultiAssayExperiment (MAE) object identifies taxa OTU level choice exhibit relative abundance greater equal relative abundance percent threshold, relabu_threshold, least occur_pct_cutoff% total samples. filtration, taxa across specified OTU level downstream levels consolidated category "".

title: Filter a MultiAssayExperiment object to keep a top percentage of taxa — filter_MAE
code: filter_MAE(   dat,   relabu_threshold = 3,   occur_pct_cutoff = 5,   taxon_level = "genus" )

title: Filter a MultiAssayExperiment object to keep a top percentage of taxa — filter_MAE
text: dat MultiAssayExperiment object specially formatted animalcules output. relabu_threshold double(percentage) 0 100, representing relative abundance criterion OTUs meet retained. smaller threshold, fewer OTUs retained. Default 3%. occur_pct_cutoff double (percentage) 0 100 representing percent cutoff many OTUs must meet relabu_threshold across samples retained. wise keep number samples mind setting parameter. Default 5%. taxon_level Character string indicating level taxonomy aggregate counts data. Must name column MultiAssayExperiment::rowData(dat).

title: Filter a MultiAssayExperiment object to keep a top percentage of taxa — filter_MAE
text: animalcules-formatted MultiAssayExperiment object major OTUs retained.

title: Filter a MultiAssayExperiment object to keep a top percentage of taxa — filter_MAE
code: in_dat <- system.file("extdata/MAE_small.RDS", package = "LegATo") |>     readRDS()   filter_MAE(in_dat, relabu_threshold = 3, occur_pct_cutoff = 5,              taxon_level = "genus") #> The overall range of relative abundance counts between samples is (590, 238823)  #> Number of OTUs that exhibit a relative abundance >3% in at least 5% of the total samples: 54/100 #> A MultiAssayExperiment object of 1 listed #>  experiment with a user-defined name and respective class. #>  Containing an ExperimentList class object of length 1: #>  [1] MicrobeGenetics: SummarizedExperiment with 54 rows and 50 columns #> Functionality: #>  experiments() - obtain the ExperimentList instance #>  colData() - the primary/phenotype DataFrame #>  sampleMap() - the sample coordination DataFrame #>  `$`, `[`, `[[` - extract colData columns, subset, or experiment #>  *Format() - convert into a long or wide DataFrame #>  assays() - convert ExperimentList to a SimpleList of matrices #>  exportClass() - save data to flat files

what: Filter a MultiAssayExperiment to a top percentage of taxa and label the rest as
title: Filter a MultiAssayExperiment to a top percentage of taxa and label the rest as

what: Create a long data.frame from a MultiAssayExperiment counts object — get_long_data

title: Create a long data.frame from a MultiAssayExperiment counts object — get_long_data
code: get_long_data(dat, taxon_level, log = FALSE, counts_to_CPM = FALSE)

title: Create a long data.frame from a MultiAssayExperiment counts object — get_long_data
text: dat MultiAssayExperiment object specially formatted animalcules output. taxon_level Character string indicating level taxonomy aggregate counts data. Must name column MultiAssayExperiment::rowData(dat). log logical. Indicate whether assay returned log whichever assay specified "output_name". counts_to_CPM = TRUE well, log CPM assay also created. Default FALSE. counts_to_CPM logical. argument applies input_type counts assay. TRUE, output assays include normalized CPM assay. log = TRUE well, log CPM assay also created. Default TRUE.

text: data.frame consisting counts data, taxa,   metadata.

what: Create a table summarizing reads aggregated by grouping variables on a unit — get_summary_table
title: Create a table summarizing reads aggregated by grouping variables on a unit — get_summary_table
text: function takes MultiAssayExperiment microbial read counts aggregates one grouping vars within unit.

title: Create a table summarizing reads aggregated by grouping variables on a unit — get_summary_table
code: get_summary_table(dat, group_vars = NULL)

title: Create a table summarizing reads aggregated by grouping variables on a unit — get_summary_table
text: dat MultiAssayExperiment object specially formatted animalcules output. group_vars character string character vector covariates found colData(dat) use grouping counts. variables listed order desired grouping. Default NULL, rely grouping variable instead produces statistics entirety data.

title: Create a table summarizing reads aggregated by grouping variables on a unit — get_summary_table
text: data.frame grouping columns, mean_reads, sd_reads, min_reads, max_reads num_total.

title: Create a table summarizing reads aggregated by grouping variables on a unit — get_summary_table
code: in_dat <- system.file("extdata/MAE_small.RDS", package = "LegATo") |> readRDS() out <- get_summary_table(in_dat, c("Group", "Subject")) head(out) #>   Group Subject mean_reads  sd_reads min_reads max_reads num_total #> 1     A      S1     7695.6  5583.400      1492     16804         5 #> 2     A      S3    51285.0 68211.168       590    153641         5 #> 3     A      S5    28239.8 50681.578      2829    118800         5 #> 4     A      S7    24921.8 49282.734      1345    113053         5 #> 5     A      S9    25595.8 23398.934      3428     64845         5 #> 6     B     S10     3406.2  2668.049       911      7543         5

what: Parse a MultiExperimentAssay object and extract the elements as data.frames — parse_MAE_SE
title: Parse a MultiExperimentAssay object and extract the elements as data.frames — parse_MAE_SE
text: function takes animalcules-formatted MultiAssayExperiment object parses extract named assay alongside taxonomy metadata.

title: Parse a MultiExperimentAssay object and extract the elements as data.frames — parse_MAE_SE
code: parse_MAE_SE(dat, which_assay = NULL, type = "MAE")

title: Parse a MultiExperimentAssay object and extract the elements as data.frames — parse_MAE_SE
text: dat Either MultiAssayExperiment SummarizedExperiment object. which_assay Character string. refers assay extracted MultiAssayExperiment object type = "MAE". need specified type = "SE". Default NULL. type One "MAE" denoting MultiAssayExperiment "SE" denoting SummarizedExperiment.

title: Parse a MultiExperimentAssay object and extract the elements as data.frames — parse_MAE_SE
text: Returns list 3 named data.frame elements, `counts`, `sam`,   `tax` denoting counts data, sample metadata table, taxonomy table,   respectively.

what: Plot an alluvial diagram of microbial relative abundance — plot_alluvial
title: Plot an alluvial diagram of microbial relative abundance — plot_alluvial
text: function takes MultiAssayExperiment object returns alluvial diagram microbe relative abundances. function takes single covariate optional variable create grid multiple plots. Note, ggalluvial package required use function.

title: Plot an alluvial diagram of microbial relative abundance — plot_alluvial
code: plot_alluvial(   dat,   taxon_level,   covariate_1 = NULL,   covariate_time,   palette_input = NULL,   title = paste("Relative abundance at", taxon_level, "level"),   subtitle = NULL )

title: Plot an alluvial diagram of microbial relative abundance — plot_alluvial
text: dat MultiAssayExperiment object specially formatted animalcules output. taxon_level Character string indicating level taxonomy aggregate counts data. Must name column MultiAssayExperiment::rowData(dat). covariate_1 Character string giving name column MultiAssayExperiment::colData(dat) create multiple plots. default NULL. covariate_time Character string giving name discrete time-based covariate metadata group abundances . palette_input character vector colors minimum length number taxa (specified taxon_level). default NULL relies ggplot2's default scheme. title character string providing plot title. subtitle character string providing plot subtitle. default NULL.

title: Plot an alluvial diagram of microbial relative abundance — plot_alluvial
text: ggplot2 plot.

title: Plot an alluvial diagram of microbial relative abundance — plot_alluvial
text: manipulation specific parameters desired, users can add ggplot2 function calls output function.

title: Plot an alluvial diagram of microbial relative abundance — plot_alluvial
code: in_dat <- system.file("extdata/MAE_small.RDS", package = "LegATo") |> readRDS() plot_alluvial(in_dat, taxon_level = "family", covariate_1 = "Group", covariate_time = "Month",               palette_input = rainbow(25))

title: Plot a ComplexHeatmap. — plot_heatmap
text: function takes arbitrary dataset input returns ComplexHeatmap plot samples based similarity microbial abundances. function takes arguments listed well others passed ComplexHeatmap::Heatmap(). Note, "circlize" "ComplexHeatmap" packages required use function.

title: Plot a ComplexHeatmap. — plot_heatmap
code: plot_heatmap(   inputData,   annotationData = NULL,   plot_title = NULL,   name = "Input data",   plottingColNames,   annotationColNames = NULL,   colList = list(),   scale = FALSE,   showColumnNames = TRUE,   showRowNames = TRUE,   colorSets = c("Set1", "Set2", "Set3", "Pastel1", "Pastel2", "Accent", "Dark2",     "Paired"),   choose_color = c("blue", "gray95", "red"),   split_heatmap = "none",   annotationplotting = NULL,   column_order = NULL,   ... )

title: Plot a ComplexHeatmap. — plot_heatmap
text: inputData input data object. either class SummarizedExperiment contain data annotation data columns colData, alternatively classes data.frame matrix contain plotting data. Required. annotationData data.frame matrix annotation data, one column. required inputData data.frame matrix plotting data. row names must equal inputData column names. Default NULL. plot_title character string plot title heatmap. default NULL. name character string name data displayed. Default "Input data". plottingColNames vector column names colData contain plotting data. required inputData SummarizedExperiment object. annotationColNames vector column names colData contain annotation data. required inputData SummarizedExperiment. Default NULL. colList named list named vectors specifying custom color information pass ComplexHeatmap::Heatmap(). list many elements annotation columns, element name correspond exactly name annotation column. colors vector elements named according levels factor column's annotation data annotation discrete, produced circlize::colorRamp2 annotation continuous. default, ColorBrewer color sets used. See parameter colorSets additional details. scale logical. Setting scale = TRUE scales plotting data. default FALSE. showColumnNames logical. Setting showColumnNames = TRUE show column names (.e. sample names) heatmap. default TRUE. showRowNames logical. Setting showColumnNames = TRUE show row names (.e. plotting names) heatmap. default TRUE. colorSets vector names listing color sets order used creating heatmap. default, function use color sets order listed Usage annotation information. may replace default collection sets order want use , provide custom color sets colList parameter. choose_color vector color names interpolated heatmap gradient, colorRamp function produced circlize::colorRamp2. default c("blue", "gray95", "red"). split_heatmap character string either giving column title annotationplotting containing annotation data split heatmap rows, "none" split desired. annotationplotting data.frame matrix information used splitting heatmap. first column plotting names. column annotation information specified split_heatmap. columns ignored. default sigAnnotData. column_order vector character strings indicating order manually arrange heatmap columns. Default NULL, column order automatically determined via clustering. ... Additional arguments passed ComplexHeatmap::Heatmap().

from ‘package:matrixStats’: #>  #>     colAlls, colAnyNAs, colAnys, colAvgsPerRowSet, colCollapse, #>     colCounts, colCummaxs, colCummins, colCumprods, colCumsums, #>     colDiffs, colIQRDiffs, rowCollapse, rowCounts, rowCummaxs, rowCummins, rowCumprods, #>     rowCumsums, rowDiffs, rowIQRDiffs, rowIQRs, rowLogSumExps, #>     rowMadDiffs, rowMads, rowMaxs, rowMeans2, rowMedians, rowMins, #> anyDuplicated, aperm, append, #>     as.data.frame, basename, cbind, colnames, dirname, do.call, #>     duplicated, eval, evalq, get, grep, grepl, intersect, is.unsorted, #>     lapply, mapply, match, mget, order, paste, pmax, pmax.int, pmin, #>     pmin.int, rank, rbind, rownames, sapply, setdiff, table, tapply, #>     union, unique, unsplit, which.max, which.min #> Loading required package: S4Vectors #>  #> Attaching package: ‘S4Vectors’ #> The following object is masked from ‘package:utils’: #>  #>     findMatches #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     I, expand.grid, unname #> Loading required package: IRanges #> Loading required package: GenomeInfoDb #> Loading required package: Biobase #> Welcome to Bioconductor #>  #>     Vignettes contain introductory material; view with #>     'browseVignettes()'. To cite Bioconductor, see #>     'citation("Biobase")', and for packages 'citation("pkgname")'. #>  #> Attaching package: ‘Biobase’ #> The following object is masked from ‘package:MatrixGenerics’: #>  #>     rowMedians #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:matrixStats’: #>  #>     anyMissing, rowMedians # Example with a Summarized Experiment data object dat <- system.file("extdata/MAE_small.RDS", package = "LegATo") |> readRDS() input_SE <- dat[["MicrobeGenetics"]]  ## Creating a continuous color ramp annot col list Hairrange <- range(colData(input_SE)[, "HairLength"]) color2 <- circlize::colorRamp2(c(Hairrange[1], Hairrange[2]), c("blue", "red")) color.list <- list("HairLength" = color2)  ## Create plot plot_heatmap(   inputData = input_SE,   name = "Microbe abundances",   plot_title = "Example Heatmap",   plottingColNames = colnames(input_SE),   annotationColNames = "HairLength",   colList = color.list,   scale = TRUE,   showColumnNames = TRUE,   showRowNames = FALSE,   colorSets =      c("Set1", "Set2", "Set3", "Pastel1", "Pastel2", "Accent", "Dark2",       "Paired"),   choose_color = c("blue", "gray95", "red"),   split_heatmap = "none",   column_order = NULL )  #> NULL  # Artificial data example - matrix input mat_testdata <- rbind(matrix(c(rnorm(80), rnorm(80) + 5), 16, 10,                              dimnames = list(paste0("Taxon", seq_len(16)),                                              paste0("sample", seq_len(10)))),                       matrix(rnorm(1000), 100, 10,                              dimnames = list(paste0("Taxon0", seq_len(100)),                                              paste0("sample", seq_len(10))))) cov_mat <- data.frame(sample = c(rep("down", 5), rep("up", 5))) |>   magrittr::set_rownames(paste0("sample", seq_len(10)))  # Example using custom colors for the annotation information color2 <- stats::setNames(c("purple", "black"), c("down", "up")) color.list <- list("sample" = color2)  plot_heatmap(   inputData = mat_testdata,   annotationData = cov_mat,   name = "Data",   plot_title = "Example",   plottingColNames = NULL,   annotationColNames = NULL,   colList = color.list,   scale = FALSE,   showColumnNames = TRUE,   showRowNames = FALSE,   colorSets = c("Set1", "Set2", "Set3", "Pastel1", "Pastel2", "Accent", "Dark2",                 "Paired"),   choose_color = c("blue", "gray95", "red"),   split_heatmap = "none",   column_order = NULL )  #> NULL

code: plot_spaghetti(   dat,   covariate_time,   covariate_1 = NULL,   unit_var,   taxon_level,   which_taxon,   palette_input = NULL,   title = "Spaghetti Plot",   subtitle = NULL )

title: Plot a spaghetti volatility plot of microbial abundance for a given taxon — plot_spaghetti
text: dat MultiAssayExperiment object specially formatted animalcules output. covariate_time Character string giving name discrete time-based covariate metadata group abundances . covariate_1 Character string, name covariate `dat` color group samples. Default NULL. unit_var Character string, name column delineating unit microbial abundances changing time. likely something akin subject repeated measurements made . taxon_level Character string indicating level taxonomy aggregate counts data. Must name column MultiAssayExperiment::rowData(dat). which_taxon Character string, name taxon plot specified taxon level. palette_input character vector colors minimum length number taxa (specified taxon_level). default NULL relies ggplot2's default scheme. title character string providing plot title. subtitle character string providing plot subtitle. default NULL.

what: Compute Generalized Estimating Equations (GEEs) on longitudinal microbiome data — run_gee_model
title: Compute Generalized Estimating Equations (GEEs) on longitudinal microbiome data — run_gee_model
text: function takes animalcules-formatted MultiAssayExperiment runs independent GEE model taxon. model predicts taxon log CPM abundance product fixed-effects covariates conditional grouping ID variable, usually unit repeated measurements taken. modeling approach works best small datasets multiple samples across many (>40) clusters/units. Note, "broom", "ggeffects", "broom.mixed", "geepack", "emmeans" packages required use function; can installed via CRAN.

title: Compute Generalized Estimating Equations (GEEs) on longitudinal microbiome data — run_gee_model
code: run_gee_model(   dat,   taxon_level = "genus",   unit_var,   fixed_cov,   corstr = "ar1",   p_adj_method = "fdr",   plot_out = FALSE,   plotsave_loc = ".",   plot_terms = NULL,   ... )

title: Compute Generalized Estimating Equations (GEEs) on longitudinal microbiome data — run_gee_model
text: dat MultiAssayExperiment object specially formatted animalcules output. taxon_level Character string, default "genus". unit_var Character string giving variable containing identifiers unit multiple measurements conducted, e.g. subjects. Default NULL; must supplied paired = FALSE. fixed_cov character vector naming covariates tested. corstr character string specifying correlation structure. following permitted: '"independence"', '"exchangeable"', '"ar1"', '"unstructured"'. p_adj_method character string specifying correction method. Can abbreviated. See details. Default "fdr". plot_out Logical indicating whether plots output alongside model results. Default FALSE. plotsave_loc character string giving folder path save plot outputs. defaults current working directory. plot_terms Character vector. terms examined plot output? Can overlap fixed_cov inputs. ... arguments passed ggsave plot creation.

title: Compute Generalized Estimating Equations (GEEs) on longitudinal microbiome data — run_gee_model
text: data.frame modeling results.

title: Compute Generalized Estimating Equations (GEEs) on longitudinal microbiome data — run_gee_model
text: P-values adjusted model coefficients within taxon. following methods permitted: c("holm", "hochberg", "hommel", "bonferroni", "BH", "", "fdr", "none")

title: Compute Generalized Estimating Equations (GEEs) on longitudinal microbiome data — run_gee_model
code: in_dat <- system.file("extdata/MAE_small.RDS", package = "LegATo") |>               readRDS() out <- run_gee_model(in_dat, taxon_level = "genus", unit_var = "Subject",                      fixed_cov = c("HairLength", "Age", "Group", "Sex"),                      corstr = "ar1") head(out) #>   Coefficient Coefficient Estimate Standard Error  Statistic Unadj p-value #> 1 (Intercept)            4704.2733     9242.28654  0.2590754   0.610756059 #> 2 (Intercept)           27036.2185    13974.99000  3.7427333   0.053037617 #> 3 (Intercept)            1139.1468      393.29821  8.3891008   0.003774776 #> 4 (Intercept)             271.1042       84.54737 10.2818739   0.001343434 #> 5 (Intercept)             210.2923       72.45671  8.4234430   0.003704137 #> 6 (Intercept)             893.8138      386.92571  5.3362838   0.020885952 #>   Lower 95% CI Upper 95% CI              Taxon Adj p-value #> 1 -13410.27548   22818.8220      Acinetobacter  0.63983968 #> 2   -354.25853   54426.6956    Corynebacterium  0.09723563 #> 3    368.29643    1909.9971     Staphylococcus  0.02768169 #> 4    105.39440     436.8140 Noviherbaspirillum  0.02768169 #> 5     68.27979     352.3049            Kocuria  0.02768169 #> 6    135.45333    1652.1742        Pseudomonas  0.04594909

title: Compute linear models (LM) on microbiome data — run_lm_model
text: function takes animalcules-formatted MultiAssayExperiment runs independent linear model taxon. model predicts taxon log CPM abundance product user-specified covariates. model can used general microbiome analyses without repeated measures data. Note, "broom", "broom.mixed" packages required use testing functionality package; can installed via CRAN.

Default FALSE. plotsave_loc character string giving folder path save plot outputs. defaults current working directory. plot_terms Character vector. terms examined plot output? what: Compute linear mixed-effects models (LMM) on longitudinal microbiome data — run_lmm_model
title: Compute linear mixed-effects models (LMM) on longitudinal microbiome data — run_lmm_model
text: function takes animalcules-formatted MultiAssayExperiment runs independent LMM model taxon. model predicts taxon log CPM abundance product fixed-effects covariates random effect, usually unit repeated measurements taken. Note, 'broom', 'lmerTest', 'broom.mixed' packages required use function; can downloaded CRAN.

title: Compute linear mixed-effects models (LMM) on longitudinal microbiome data — run_lmm_model
code: run_lmm_model(   dat,   taxon_level = "genus",   unit_var,   fixed_cov,   p_adj_method = "fdr",   plot_out = FALSE,   plotsave_loc = ".",   plot_terms = NULL,   ... )

title: Compute linear mixed-effects models (LMM) on longitudinal microbiome data — run_lmm_model
text: dat MultiAssayExperiment object specially formatted animalcules output. taxon_level Character string, default "genus". unit_var Character string giving variable containing identifiers unit multiple measurements conducted, e.g. subjects. Default NULL; must supplied paired = FALSE. fixed_cov character vector naming covariates tested. p_adj_method character string specifying correction method. Can abbreviated. See details. Default "fdr". plot_out Logical indicating whether plots output alongside model results. Default FALSE. plotsave_loc character string giving folder path save plot outputs. defaults current working directory. plot_terms Character vector. terms examined plot output? Can overlap fixed_cov inputs. ... arguments passed ggsave plot creation.

title: Compute linear mixed-effects models (LMM) on longitudinal microbiome data — run_lmm_model
text: data.frame modeling results.

title: Compute linear mixed-effects models (LMM) on longitudinal microbiome data — run_lmm_model
text: P-values adjusted model coefficients within taxon. following methods permitted: c("holm", "hochberg", "hommel", "bonferroni", "BH", "", "fdr", "none")

what: Conduct a multivariate Hotelling's T-squared test — test_hotelling_t2
title: Conduct a multivariate Hotelling's T-squared test — test_hotelling_t2
text: function takes animalcules-formatted MultiAssayExperiment object runs multivariate Hotelling's T-squared test. test expects comparison two distinct groups, compares abundances top microbes given taxon level groups. function allows paired unpaired tests. test null hypothesis population mean vectors equal, alternative unequal.

title: Conduct a multivariate Hotelling's T-squared test — test_hotelling_t2
code: test_hotelling_t2(   dat,   test_index = NULL,   taxon_level = "genus",   num_taxa,   grouping_var,   paired = FALSE,   pairing_var = NULL,   unit_var = NULL,   save_table_loc = "." )

title: Conduct a multivariate Hotelling's T-squared test — test_hotelling_t2
text: dat MultiAssayExperiment object specially formatted animalcules output. test_index argument used subsetting input dat, can character, logical, integer, list List vector. Default NULL. taxon_level Character string, default "genus". num_taxa number abundant taxa test. unpaired, larger total number subjects groups - 2, (n1 + n2 -2). paired, larger total number pairs - 1, n - 1. Required. grouping_var Character string, name DICHOTOMOUS grouping variable metadata dat. paired Logical indicating whether paired test conducted. Default FALSE unpaired test. pairing_var Character string giving variable containing pairing information. variable integer form. Must supplied paired = TRUE, otherwise default NULL. unit_var Character string giving variable containing identifiers unit multiple measurements conducted, e.g. subjects. Default NULL; must supplied paired = FALSE. save_table_loc character string giving folder path save t.test results. Note conducted Hotelling's T-test value <0.05.  Defaults current working directory.

title: Conduct a multivariate Hotelling's T-squared test — test_hotelling_t2
text: list elements "df1", "df2", "crit_F", "F_stat" "pvalue" giving results test.

title: Conduct a multivariate Hotelling's T-squared test — test_hotelling_t2
text: Hotelling's t-squared statistic (t2) generalization Student's t-statistic used multivariate hypothesis testing test means different populations. Note entries pairs missing values excluded. Referenced articles implementation tests: https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat505/lesson/7/7.1/7.1.14 https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat505/lesson/7/7.1/7.1.15 https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat505/lesson/7/7.1/7.1.4 https://online.stat.psu.edu/stat505/lesson/7/7.1/7.1.9

title: Conduct a multivariate Hotelling's T-squared test — test_hotelling_t2
code: dat <- system.file("extdata", "MAE.RDS", package = "LegATo") |> readRDS() dat_0.05 <- filter_MAE(dat, 0.001, 10, "species") #> The overall range of relative abundance counts between samples is (13218, 3016276)  #> Number of OTUs that exhibit a relative abundance >0.001% in at least 10% of the total samples: 93/1690 out1 <- test_hotelling_t2(dat = dat_0.05,                   test_index = which(dat_0.05$MothChild == "Infant" &                                        dat_0.05$timepoint == 0),                   taxon_level = "genus",                   # Total number of pairs - 1                   num_taxa = 9,                   paired = TRUE,                   grouping_var = "HIVStatus",                   pairing_var = "pairing") out1                   #> $df1 #> [1] 9 #>  #> $df2 #> [1] 1 #>  #> $crit_F #> [1] 240.5433 #>  #> $F_stat #> [1] 0.3869031 #>  #> $pvalue #> [1] 0.8576324 #>   out <- test_hotelling_t2(dat = dat_0.05,                   test_index = which(dat_0.05$MothChild == "Mother" &                                        dat_0.05$timepoint == 6),                   taxon_level = "genus",                   # Max is Total number of subjects - 2                   # Here we use a much smaller number                   num_taxa = 6,                   grouping_var = "HIVStatus",                   unit_var = "Subject",                   paired = FALSE) out                   #> $df1 #> [1] 6 #>  #> $df2 #> [1] 11 #>  #> $crit_F #> [1] 3.094613 #>  #> $F_stat #> [1] 1.591778 #>  #> $pvalue #> [1] 0.2384123 #>

title: Calculate within-subject OTU correlations — tscor
text: function takes MultiAssayExperiment outputs array temporal intra-subject correlation matrices.

title: Calculate within-subject OTU correlations — tscor
code: tscor(dat, unit_var, method = "kendall", fill_na = 0)

title: Calculate within-subject OTU correlations — tscor
text: dat MultiAssayExperiment object specially formatted animalcules output. unit_var numeric vector subject. method option correlation method ("pearson", "kendall", "spearman"). default method "kendall". fill_na number 0 1 fill missing value. default value 0.

title: Calculate within-subject OTU correlations — tscor
text: three-dimensional array temporal correlation matrices   subject.
